name: Swiftcurrent & Josephine Lakes, Glacier National Park
description: Known as the "Switzerland of North America," this area features striking scenery with backdrops of Mount Gould and Grinnell Point, offering diverse photo opportunities for landscape and portrait photography.
tips: Bring mosquito spray as they are aggressive during golden hour
Carry bear spray for safety
Great for wildlife photography including bears, moose, and mountain goats
Hike from Swiftcurrent to Josephine Lake for varied scenes

name: Lake McDonald
description: Lake McDonald is one of the few places in the park where the views are spectacular without a long hike. It features countless little coves and a dock in Apgar that provide primo spots for photography.
tips: Use the dock in Apgar for a classic perspective
Explore the shoreline to find peaceful, private coves
It is drive-up accessible, making it easy to bring heavy gear

name: Sun point Nature Trail
description: A short, scenic hike offering breathtaking views of St. Mary Lake and surrounding peaks, perfect for capturing wildflowers and tranquil lake shores.
tips: Easy trail ideal for spotting wildflowers
Capture the dramatic landscape and tranquil lake shores

name: The Grinnell Glacier Trail
description: This trail in the Many Glacier area offers a high 'wow factor' with spectacular views that begin early in the hike and improve with every step as you leave the trees.
tips: Look for Mountain Goats along the trail as they often pose for photos
Capture the waterfalls along the route for dramatic shots
The Garden Wall looks particularly good in evening light

name: Apgar Village Shoreline
description: A gathering spot for sunset where the mountains turn soft purple and the water is calm.
tips: No hiking required
Look for purple hues on the mountains

name: Lake McDonald, Glacier National Park
description: The largest lake in the park, famous for its colorful pebbles and calm waters that reflect the fiery hues of the sun.
tips: Use a 10-stop filter to create long exposures if the water is choppy
Be prepared for heavy mosquito activity
Plan for traffic and road construction delays along the lake
Arrive early to scout for the best vantage points of the colorful pebbles

name: Logan Pass
description: As the high point of the Going-to-the-Sun Road, Logan Pass offers diverse photography options ranging from wildflowers to expansive mountain vistas and abundant wildlife.
tips: Use a long-distance camera lens for wildlife photography (bears, goats, rams)
Take the short walk from the visitor center to the Hidden Lake Overlook
Stay after the crowds leave for a more peaceful sunset experience

name: Lake McDonald Lodge
description: The boat dock area features rustic red boats lined up against a mountain backdrop.
tips: Capture the textures and reflections of the red boats
Shoot from the boat dock area

name: Paradise Meadow, Going-to-the-Sun Road
description: A picturesque alpine meadow bursting with vibrant wildflowers and surrounded by towering peaks along the park's most scenic drive.
tips: Excellent spot for wildflower photography
Stop here while driving the 50-mile Going-to-the-Sun Road

name: Elizabeth Lake
description: A remote and highly photogenic lake in the northeast corner of the park, accessible via long hikes through the Chief Mountain Trailhead or Ptarmigan Tunnel.
tips: Carry a tripod for excellent Milky Way and night photography opportunities
Look for the pair of swans that call the lake home
Plan for a multi-day backpacking trip to capture the best morning and evening light

name: Trail of the Cedars & Avalanche Creek
description: Features milky turquoise water flowing through a canyon with accessible boardwalks.
tips: Use the boardwalk for easy access
Watch the water swirl from the railings

name: Red Rock Point, Going-to-the-Sun Road
description: A viewpoint offering stunning views of McDonald Creek's turquoise waters against dramatic red-rock cliffs.
tips: Parking is limited and challenging in summer
Walk down from the viewpoint to get up-close views of McDonald Creek

name: Granite Park Chalet
description: A historic backcountry chalet that serves as a base for exploring high-elevation terrain, including the Garden Wall and Swiftcurrent Lookout.
tips: Hike the additional 5-mile round trip to Swiftcurrent Lookout for the highest views in the park
The 3-mile out-and-back spur to Grinnell Glacier Overlook provides views looking down on the glacier
Book chalet stays well in advance as they fill up quickly

name: Avalanche Lake
description: A popular spot featuring waterfalls spilling down a cirque and still lake reflections.
tips: Bring a wide-angle lens
Arrive early to capture the lake while it is still

name: Kootenai Falls & Suspension Bridge, Montana
description: One of the largest free-flowing waterfalls in the Northwest, featuring a suspension bridge that provides a high vantage point over roaring waters.
tips: Use the suspension bridge for a thrilling high-angle perspective
Great stop for a hike to capture raw wilderness

name: West Tunnel
description: A tunnel along Going-to-the-Sun Road with windows carved into the rock that frame the mountains.
tips: Use the small pullouts before or after the tunnel
The windows act as a built-in viewfinder

name: Browning, Montana
description: The heart of the Blackfeet Nation, offering 360-degree unblocked mountain views and spectacular sunrises.
tips: Drones are permitted here as it is outside the National Park boundaries
Look for the 'Roundhouse' or similar rentals for unobstructed views

name: The Loop
description: A dramatic curve on Sun Road offering views of rocky cliffs and layers of mountain peaks.
tips: Capture the lingering snow streaks in early summer
Focus on the dramatic mountain curves

name: Triple Arches
description: A historic stone support structure with arches built into the cliff side.
tips: Frame the shot from a nearby pullout
Capture the engineering curve against the alpine backdrop

name: Bird Woman Falls Overlook
description: Provides an unobstructed view of a long ribbon waterfall cascading down massive cliffs.
tips: Use a telephoto lens for waterfall details
Use a wide-angle lens for scale

name: Weeping Wall
description: A rock face that gushes water directly beside the road during the summer snow melt.
tips: Get out for close-up shots
Be prepared to get damp from the spray

name: Big Bend
description: A major pull-off with sweeping mountain views, waterfalls, and dark sky for astrophotography.
tips: Great for Milky Way photography on clear nights
Capture cascading waterfalls from snow melt

name: Oberlin Bend Overlook
description: A high-altitude overlook with layered mountain views and frequent wildlife sightings.
tips: Bring a telephoto lens for goats and bighorn sheep
Phone cameras work well for the layered landscape

name: Hidden Lake Overlook
description: One of the most iconic views in the park, overlooking a turquoise lake framed by peaks.
tips: Use a wide-angle lens for the full lake scene
Stay on the boardwalks to protect the meadows

name: Highline Trail Entrance
description: A cliffside path providing dramatic depth and views looking back toward the road.
tips: Focus on the depth and layers of the landscape
You only need to walk a few steps for the view

name: Wild Goose Island (St. Mary Lake)
description: A tiny island in the middle of a massive lake, framed by jagged mountain peaks.
tips: Sunrise is ideal for calm water and lighting
This is a classic composition for landscape shooters

name: St. Mary Lake Pullouts
description: Multiple locations along the shore offering different mountain alignments and lighting.
tips: Stop at every pullout for unique mountain angles

name: St. Mary Falls & Virginia Falls
description: Two distinct waterfalls accessible on one trail, offering fast-flowing and misty styles.
tips: Bring a microfiber cloth to wipe mist off the lens
Use slow shutter speeds for water motion

name: Swiftcurrent Lake
description: A lake in Many Glacier that provides massive peak reflections and easy access.
tips: Wait for the quietest morning hours for mirror reflections

name: Many Glacier Hotel
description: A historic lodge with a backyard panoramic view of dramatic mountains and water.
tips: Shoot from behind the lodge for a panoramic view

name: Lake Josephine
description: A peaceful lake that is quieter than Swiftcurrent, offering excellent reflection opportunities.
tips: Best for reflections when the wind is calm

name: Iceberg Lake
description: A remote lake known for floating ice chunks and towering cliffs.
tips: Capture the scale of the cliffs against the water

name: Bowman Lake
description: A quiet, remote lake in the North Fork area with very still water.
tips: Plan for a long drive on a gravel road
Mornings are the most peaceful for photos

name: Polebridge Mercantile
description: A rustic, quirky general store area with character-filled buildings and signage.
tips: Look for personality-filled details like rustic signs

name: Two Medicine Lake
description: A less crowded area where sunrise light hits the mountain peaks in gold.
tips: Watch for gold light bouncing off the peaks in the morning

name: Running Eagle Falls
description: A unique waterfall that flows through a hole in the rock.
tips: Use slow shutter speeds for a dramatic look
